en.value: Which word in para 1 means the same as &#39;busy&#39; ?
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate option:

1. Before the electronic era, everyday reading was a ritual that almost everyone who wanted to gain knowledge adapted. Amongst other things, we have been so preoccupied with the social media and the internet that hardly anyone contemplates reading books. While some maybe too busy to read, others merely don't care to read.

2. There are many benefits to reading, from making you smarter to improving your reading and writing skills. When you read every day, you stimulate your mental activity, which allows the brain to retain its power and capacity. Just as the body needs exercise to stay healthy, the same goes for the brain. Reading gives it regular exercise and keeps it healthy and sound. Even playing games like chess or solving puzzles result in congnitive stimulation. When you read a great story, all your stress seems to slip away and relaxes you since you tend to travel mentally to a different realm. Sometimes, while reading you come across valuable advice or solutions to your everyday problems.

3. One of the great benefits of reading books is that the knowledge you gain from them can never be taken away from you. Unlike worldly possessions, your knowledge stays with you till the very end. en.value: Which of the following ideas is NOT suggested by the poet ?
en.comp:
Read the poetic lines given below and answer that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate option:

Nature! Nature! So lush and green,

The wonder of wonder anyone has seen.

So cool, calm and full of life, makes us forget all our strife.

Think of a forest full of trees, fluttering and dancing in the breeze.

Cut them down and construct towers,

Wait for ages to get a shower.

The birds that soar high in the sky

Can we imitate them however hard we try?

Learn to wonder and gape at things and see the happiness it brings.

We have got such wonderful things, do what you can and save a wing.

So that our children in future can see the things we have nurtured.

Keeping a record of all the learning activities and learners performance to account for the overall achievement of learners is known as ___________.
The word &#39;flowers&#39; in para 1 is a/an :
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate option:

1. I am often amazed by the questions children ask and the thought process they carry out to answer some of ours. Their questions and answers can be profound and thought-provoking. At times they demonstrate what we call 'critical thinking'. Our responsibility as educators, is to ensure that the 'critical thinking' capability of each student in our care flowers, rather than shrivels, as a result of their schooling.

2. My two boys aged 10 and 7 and I were toying around with a prism on the balcony of our house one night, looking at the steetlights through the prism to see light split up into different hues. There were a lot of questions. Why do we see so many colours through the prism? Why are we unable to see the split colours without the prism? Are the colours really there? There was a lot of speculations as well. Without my giving them the 'right' answers, we discussed the role of light on our ability to 'see' the world and all the colours in it. Just then there was a power cut and everything was plunged into darkness. Suddenly, after a minute of silence, I heard my eldest's voice, "The world is colourless!"

3. Children evidently have an innate ability to reason, to examine varied and complicated ideas and situations, and express them in simple terms and language. The explanation may not always be logical or scientifically accurate, but they 'make sense' and are not entirely 'wrong' either. We expect students to respect us and each other also, but what do we mean by respect? More often than not, we preach borrowed ideas and principles. An eighth grader put it across simply, "Respect means understanding the concept behind someone else's beliefs, not necessarily agreeing or following, but understanding and feeling compatibility".

There were a lot of questions. Why do we see so many colours through the prism? Why are we unable to see the split colours without the prism? Are the colours really there? There was a lot of speculations as well. Without my giving them the 'right' answers, we discussed the role of light on our ability to 'see' the world and all the colours in it. Just then there was a power cut and everything was plunged into darkness. Suddenly, after a minute of silence, I heard my eldest's voice, "The world is colourless!"

3. Children evidently have an innate ability to reason, to examine varied and complicated ideas and situations, and express them in simple terms and language. The explanation may not always be logical or scientifically accurate, but they 'make sense' and are not entirely 'wrong' either. We expect students to respect us and each other also, but what do we mean by respect? More often than not, we preach borrowed ideas and principles. An eighth grader put it across simply, "Respect means understanding the concept behind someone else's beliefs, not necessarily agreeing or following, but understanding and feeling compatibility".

en.value: Which word in para 2 will be closest in meaning to the word &#39;excitement&#39; ?
en.comp:
Read the passage given below and answer that follow by selecting the correct/most appropriate option :

1. South Africa with a new tourism slogan - Leave Ordinary Behind - is fast becoming a popular tourist destination. There are over 9,00,000 arrivals per month of which around one quarter are from outside the African continent. It generates between 1-3 percent of the GDP. Among the main attractions are the diverse and picturesque game reserves and exotic animals.

2. For the thrill seekers who visit South Africa, the unique attractions are bungee jumping and white water rafting. The country boasts of the third highest commercial bungee jump in the world. Located on the border of the Eastern and Western Cape and at the height of 216 metres, it's certainly not for the faint of heart. There is an ever-growing group of people who prefer the thrills and excitements of a rough and adrenalin packed South Africa and water rafting trips on awesome torrential rivers. Such trips promise hours of enjoyable, exhilarating and challenging adventures where rafting enthusiasts can test their skills. The Orange River in the mountainous deserts and the vall river near the capital Johannesburg are some favourite destinations.

3. South Africa has 19 national parks on 37,00,000 hectares of land, almost 3 percent of the country's total area. The Kruger National Park is the most popular among foreign tourists. It is cost effective and offers a do-it-yourself safari which is functional and affordable. Free roaming wild animals, land based whale watching, diverse eco-zones, magnificent rock formations, rolling grasslands, crystal clear streams.....yes, South Africa has it all for those visitors who want to leave the ordinary behind!
